summary:
Rhaego: ‘Mom!!! Jon yelled at me!!!’ 
Jon: ‘Aunt Dany he’s lying,’
Daenerys: ‘Rhaego what did you do?’
Rhaego: ‘I took his black...
body:
Rhaego: ‘Mom!!! Jon yelled at me!!!’


Jon: ‘Aunt Dany he’s lying,’


Daenerys: ‘Rhaego what did you do?’


Rhaego: ‘I took his black nail polish,’


Jon: ‘and?’


Rhaego: ‘spilled it on his computer,’


Daenerys: ‘Spilled it on his laptop?’


Jon: ‘Yeah, my brand new laptop,’


Daenerys: ‘Rhaego, you’re grounded,’


Rhaego: ‘But …,—,’


Jon: ‘I’ll go clean my—,’


Daenerys: ‘Rhaego go clean Jon’s laptop off,’

kill theon and i'll gut you hbo
summary:
Theon: Going to Plan B?

Jon: Technically, that would be Plan G.

Sansa: How many plans do you have? Is there like, a Plan...
body:
Theon: Going to Plan B?

Jon: Technically, that would be Plan G.

Sansa: How many plans do you have? Is there like, a Plan M?

Jon: Yeah, but Theon dies in Plan M.

Arya: I like Plan M.

title: Why Jonsa is Endgame
body:
I’ve written previously why I think Jonsa make sense in the scope of the show and there are others who have written amazing metas about how and why they make sense with regard to the books and all the foreshadowing that can be found. This post is not about that. It’s about Game of Thrones builds up expectations and anticipation for a certain something but then pull the rug from under the audience’s feet. Now, as it comes to a close, the show-runners have one last opportunity to do so.

So part of the reason I think Jon and Sansa will get together by the end of Game of Thrones is precisely because they’re not the popular ship. In fact, many people among the General Audience aren’t even considering it. Especially, in terms of marketing, they seem to be selling Joner*s .

Now, that might prompt me to think that perhaps the show will indeed go with Jonerys at the end but everything they did in-show seems to undercut their marketing. All of their scenes were lacklustre and there wasn’t an iota of chemistry between them. It’s easy to dismiss D&D as incompetent but that’s not a very fair assessment. Granted, the show is not nearly as layered or nuanced as the books but it can’t possibly compete. The show is dealing with a limited budget and limited resources. But I digress.

A lot of the interviews we’ve seen of the GoT actors imply that the end will surprise a lot of people, even shock them and that it’s bittersweet. Now, if Jonerys is the popular ship and most people are already on board with it, and if that is indeed how the show does finally end, how is that end shocking? If anything, that’s the predictable course of events.

But, if season 8 not only made explicit the political!Jon theory but also started positioning D@ny as an antagonist and finally establishing Jon and Sansa as a power team, that would, indeed, be a surprising turn of events. It would also be a bittersweet ending because most people expected D@ny and Jon to rule Westeros together and start a new Targ dynasty (Targ Restoration)

On its own, their marketing and cast interviews are far from anything concrete but view them, keeping seasons 6 and 7 in mind, and things start to become clear.

The fact that many people and fansites continue to dismiss Sansa also gives me hope. I’m only talking of the show and I love that her being a power player is a subtle thing on her part to the extent that even a of audiences miss it (well that and that some people are just blinded by misogyny) There are massive issues that will plague Jon in season 8 especially after the big reveal and the only person in a position to help him is Sansa because through the course of Season 7, she became a power in her own right, no longer dependent on Jon. She’s proven herself capable of administering and playing the Game due to her political savvy.

Due to these reasons, who better to help Jon than her?

This is nowhere are clear as i want it to be. Perhaps I’ll revisit this later.

summary: Arya never seemed to fit, no more than he had…yet she could always make Jon smile. He would give anything to be with her now, to...
caption:
Arya never seemed to fit, no more than he had…yet she could always make Jon smile. He would give anything to be with her now, to muss up her hair once more and watch her make a face, to hear her finish a sentence with him.

Jon, AGoT.

(This is Jon and Arya a few years prior to AGoT, hence why Arya is so small)

summary: Do you think we'll find out that Jon was named Aegon by Lyanna, or is that a 'show' fiction?
question: Do you think we'll find out that Jon was named Aegon by Lyanna, or is that a 'show' fiction?
answer:
That’s 100% a show fiction, I would say. For one, the only information we’ve been given about Jon’s naming states unequivocally that his name came from Ned. And for Lyanna’s sake, I certainly hope that she wasn’t interested in giving her son a Targaryen name after he was born. Even if she had left willingly with Rhaegar (which I believe she did), by the time she gave birth to Jon I think she would have been virtually imprisoned in the tower of joy for months, probably aware that her father and beloved eldest brother had been mockingly executed by the king and almost certainly aware that this man she had run away with was leaving her, probably to fight her next eldest brother and her sometime affianced (and perhaps having learned that her child’s father was dead at the hands of Robert). Unless Lyanna was really deluding herself, I cannot imagine she was in love with Rhaegar anymore, and to that end, I really doubt that she would have been interested in giving her son a Targaryen name (assuming that she was even in a headspace to do so, given the probable physical trauma of the birth and the likely postpartum infection which followed). The only things she wanted were to keep her son safe and to go home herself, back to her family, even if it were only as bones.

Pardon for exhuming an old issue, but the show severely burned me last season with its treatment of the Rhaegar-Lyanna relationship. It seems evident to me that the writers and/or showrunners are set on portraying Rhaegar and Lyanna as this pure romance which resulted in Our Hero Jon Snow Aegon Targaryen, uncluttered by the existence of Rhaegar’s other wife and children or the murderous tyranny committed by Aerys II which Rhaegar then implicitly condoned. For reasons on which I am unclear and which I don’t particularly feel like guessing, the show appears to believe that Jon being Really Royalty and a Targaryen and The True Heir to the Throne somehow makes him better than him being, well, Jon Snow - a position with which I vehemently disagree. The decision to have his “real” name be Aegon is another step in that direction, IMO.

That’s 100% a show fiction, I would say. For one, the only information we’ve been given about Jon’s naming states unequivocally that his name came from Ned. And for Lyanna’s sake, I certainly hope that she wasn’t interested in giving her son a Targaryen name after he was born. Even if she had left willingly with Rhaegar (which I believe she did), by the time she gave birth to Jon I think she would have been virtually imprisoned in the tower of joy for months, probably aware that her father and beloved eldest brother had been mockingly executed by the king and almost certainly aware that this man she had run away with was leaving her, probably to fight her next eldest brother and her sometime affianced (and perhaps having learned that her child’s father was dead at the hands of Robert). Unless Lyanna was really deluding herself, I cannot imagine she was in love with Rhaegar anymore, and to that end, I really doubt that she would have been interested in giving her son a Targaryen name (assuming that she was even in a headspace to do so, given the probable physical trauma of the birth and the likely postpartum infection which followed). The only things she wanted were to keep her son safe and to go home herself, back to her family, even if it were only as bones.

Pardon for exhuming an old issue, but the show severely burned me last season with its treatment of the Rhaegar-Lyanna relationship. It seems evident to me that the writers and/or showrunners are set on portraying Rhaegar and Lyanna as this pure romance which resulted in Our Hero Jon Snow Aegon Targaryen, uncluttered by the existence of Rhaegar’s other wife and children or the murderous tyranny committed by Aerys II which Rhaegar then implicitly condoned. For reasons on which I am unclear and which I don’t particularly feel like guessing, the show appears to believe that Jon being Really Royalty and a Targaryen and The True Heir to the Throne somehow makes him better than him being, well, Jon Snow - a position with which I vehemently disagree. The decision to have his “real” name be Aegon is another step in that direction, IMO.

For one, the only information we’ve been given about Jon’s naming states unequivocally that his name came from Ned. And for Lyanna’s sake, I certainly hope that she wasn’t interested in giving her son a Targaryen name after he was born. Even if she had left willingly with Rhaegar (which I believe she did), by the time she gave birth to Jon I think she would have been virtually imprisoned in the tower of joy for months, probably aware that her father and beloved eldest brother had been mockingly executed by the king and almost certainly aware that this man she had run away with was leaving her, probably to fight her next eldest brother and her sometime affianced (and perhaps having learned that her child’s father was dead at the hands of Robert). Unless Lyanna was really deluding herself, I cannot imagine she was in love with Rhaegar anymore, and to that end, I really doubt that she would have been interested in giving her son a Targaryen name (assuming that she was even in a headspace to do so, given the probable physical trauma of the birth and the likely postpartum infection which followed). The only things she wanted were to keep her son safe and to go home herself, back to her family, even if it were only as bones.

Pardon for exhuming an old issue, but the show severely burned me last season with its treatment of the Rhaegar-Lyanna relationship. It seems evident to me that the writers and/or showrunners are set on portraying Rhaegar and Lyanna as this pure romance which resulted in Our Hero Jon Snow Aegon Targaryen, uncluttered by the existence of Rhaegar’s other wife and children or the murderous tyranny committed by Aerys II which Rhaegar then implicitly condoned. For reasons on which I am unclear and which I don’t particularly feel like guessing, the show appears to believe that Jon being Really Royalty and a Targaryen and The True Heir to the Throne somehow makes him better than him being, well, Jon Snow - a position with which I vehemently disagree. The decision to have his “real” name be Aegon is another step in that direction, IMO.

title: Jonerys Anniversary
body:
Hello fan-ladies and fan-gentlemen! So as some of you might know, our boatsex anniversary is coming up soon (August 27) and I thought it would be really cool if we all posted a little something on the day of?

I know I love anything coming from my fandom, whether its fics, fanart, metas, videos, or memes. Those who know will be busy by next week could maybe add something to a queue? 

It’s a very special date for our fandom, and I’m going to do my part of celebrating by updating chapter 3 of my fic on that day. This isn’t some organized event, so don’t feel pressured if you can’t make anything, but I’d love to celebrate the beginning of the end for Game of Thrones. 

Some of us might lose contact after the show is over, you never know, so we might as well enjoy the mystery of what is coming while we still have it.

summary: “The North is Invulnerable to Attacks From the South”
body:
“The North is Invulnerable to Attacks From the South”

Is something that a lot of people in this fandom believe and it’s fucking laughable. Tell that to the Ironborn. They seemed to have wreaked havoc on the North just fine without having to bleed through the Moat.

So stop with the absurd “Dany should have just marched North and forgot about Cersei” because Cersei has a fleet and an army on the fleet headed to Westeros and it’s not out of the question for them to attack White Harbor and land and utterly destroy the North as Winterfell and Dany’s forces are attacked from the North and South.

Basically, Dany SHOULD have melted the Red Keep with Cersei in it. It would have given her control of Westeros with limited casualties. There’s a thousand people MAX in the castle itself?

And spare me the whole “it would have destroyed the city because of the wildfire” nonsense as if we didn’t see Cersei blow up the Sept of Baelor using wildfire without it engulfing the city.

In short: the men advising Daenerys are stupid, Jon included and she shouldn’t have listened to them. Had she just melted the Red Keep in Episode 2 the realm would have been much better off.

blog.title: JustTheonGreyjoy
blog.description: Cis woman, Vienna. I'm really just here to stalk everything Game of Thrones... especially Theon Greyjoy. And post about works on AO3 :) (you can find me there as theonsfavouritetoy) Now also Drarry *sigh* AO3 for that is theboywiththeskulltattoo ;)

summary:
Hulloooo! Tagged for this by @selkiewife and @wynafryd-manderly - thanks ladies :)
Rules: list the first lines of the last ten...
body:
Hulloooo! Tagged for this by @selkiewife and @wynafryd-manderly - thanks ladies :)


Rules: list the first lines of the last ten published stories. Look to see if there is only patterns that you notice yourself, and see if anyone else notices any! Tag up to 10 friends.


***


At first the dream was nothing new, just another in a long line of visions and glimpses of the future. (from my horrible vamps AU, don’t read it)


“He’s touching him. I can totally see he’s doing it on purpose.” (a silly greysnow ficlet)


One of his better ideas, Theon thinks as he peers over the edge of the newspaper he’s holding. (from Games we play)


He’s heard some men say, when you’re dying or close to, your whole life flickers past in your mind. (from the follow-up to my soulmate AU, go read those :))


If anything, Jon would’ve thought Theon’s term abroad would only bring benefits with it. (from my smutty facetime story)


Five weeks. Five stupid weeks since that stupid highschool trip. (from one of my jondry ficlets)


Those moments aren’t frequent enough to really make him think about moving out. (from my poor, lonely Jon/Robb ficlet)


There’s heart-shaped, red confetti on the table. (from my equally lonely Throbb ficlet)


Fucking great. (from my throbb assignment story for @robb-greyjoy - still embarrassed about that one 😆)


Jon is five when it starts to appear, not a distinct shape yet, just a blurry spot on his wrist. (from my soulmate AU - go read it 😜)


So. I cannot notice any pattern, but then I’m pretty shite at that stuff. Tell me if you notice any pls :)

Tagging @quicksilvermaid, @bloggish, @repeat-script and @callmejude - if you want to, of course :)

blog.name: turtle-paced
blog.title: turtle-paced
blog.description: Writing at the speed of the race course paradox.

summary: One of the first things Jon says about himself is that bastards need to be good at reading people, or something like that. But...
question: One of the first things Jon says about himself is that bastards need to be good at reading people, or something like that. But he was wrong debating Robb about Gared's courage, he called Myrcella as insipid, but she's the best of her sibs, Noye had to point out his classmates were afraid of him, Mance notes he's got blindspots and he got blind-sided & assassinated by a group mutiny, despite his dad teaching him that commander has to know his men. Did GRRM forget or was it just emo-Jon?
answer:
Everyone in this series has blind spots, even the smart characters. I’d argue that the blind spots of the most intelligent characters are all the more glaring because the reader doesn’t expect to see them. Tyrion gets blindsided by his fall at the end of ACoK, Catelyn cannot accurately assess Jon’s character, Sansa’s extremely clever but judges just about everyone wrong in AGoT, Tywin gets crossbowed in the guts for his blind spot, Davos has trouble seeing Melisandre’s intentions, Melisandre can’t see her own fallibility, Stannis can’t look past his grudges and misogyny, Dany gets caught in the Sunk Costs Fallacy in Meereen and puts more and more effort into the wrong sort of peace.

And Jon, who is 100% on the money in judging Marsh and his ilk bigots who are too timid to face the entirety of what’s coming, misjudges the extent of their reactionary angst. He’s no exception to that long list of smart people with flawed perceptions.

Jon’s biggest blind spot, especially early in the series, is definitely the chip on his shoulder. That’s why he didn’t see his fellow Watch recruits were scared of him and saw him as a bully. It’s also why he thinks Myrcella’s insipid; that judgment was made at a feast where he’s sitting up the back brooding on why he can’t sit with his family, and he directs his resentment to the person who actually got to sit with Robb and enjoy his company.

I will defend Jon’s take on Gared, though.

“Robb says the man died bravely, but Jon says he was afraid.”

“What do you think?” his father asked.

Bran thought about it. “Can a man still be brave if he’s afraid?”

“That is the only time a man can be brave,” his father told him.

- Bran I, AGoT

The point is that Jon and Robb were both correct, but neither were as correct as they could have been. The answers they gave demonstrates their respective personalities. Robb, who’s had a charmed life, sees the best in Gared; Jon, who’s seen a bit more nastiness, sees the weakness. Bran’s answer is the best of the three, but it doesn’t make Jon’s call wrong.

And Jon, who is 100% on the money in judging Marsh and his ilk bigots who are too timid to face the entirety of what’s coming, misjudges the extent of their reactionary angst. He’s no exception to that long list of smart people with flawed perceptions.

Jon’s biggest blind spot, especially early in the series, is definitely the chip on his shoulder. That’s why he didn’t see his fellow Watch recruits were scared of him and saw him as a bully. It’s also why he thinks Myrcella’s insipid; that judgment was made at a feast where he’s sitting up the back brooding on why he can’t sit with his family, and he directs his resentment to the person who actually got to sit with Robb and enjoy his company.

I will defend Jon’s take on Gared, though.

“Robb says the man died bravely, but Jon says he was afraid.”

“What do you think?” his father asked.

Bran thought about it. “Can a man still be brave if he’s afraid?”

“That is the only time a man can be brave,” his father told him.

- Bran I, AGoT

The point is that Jon and Robb were both correct, but neither were as correct as they could have been. The answers they gave demonstrates their respective personalities. Robb, who’s had a charmed life, sees the best in Gared; Jon, who’s seen a bit more nastiness, sees the weakness. Bran’s answer is the best of the three, but it doesn’t make Jon’s call wrong.
